 Space Considerations

On 27 August 2013 15:54, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
>
> Just to assure that I understand you correct: you are working with objective
> fitness functions, not a co-evolution approach where a geo-location might also
> play an important role!?

Correct, that is, I'm *not* referring to a typical co-evolution set-up
where you have agents in a world competing with each other in some
geo-space (e.g. foraging for limited food). What I'm suggesting is
taking an objective fn where typically we evaluate each genome in
isolation from all others, but now we adjust the fitness of each
genome based on this other information - the genome's position in some
2D space and the density of other genomes in around that position.


> You wrote, population density should adjust the fitness. This means, two
> species cannot share the same area (or don't you use the concept of >>species)!?

For this research direction forget about species and go back to just a
population of genomes with no other structure to the population - and
now assign each genome a 2D coord.


> Do you aim to model something in analogy to nature? Then, I don't get the link. In
> natural systems (which is based on co-evolution and open-ended) the location on
> earth determines what is the predator > and what is the prey,

That's largely (or entirely) due to environmental variation. If I'm
swimming in the sea there are sharks, if I'm on an American mountain
then lookout for mountain lions, and if I'm in temperate region forest
then beware of bears. We can certainly develop the idea to have
variation in the geo-space, but for now I'm proposing that the space
be homogeneous.

Fit genomes will spawn offspring nearby, which will result in a
cluster of similar genomes, but one that is self limiting in size
because genomes in that cluster will have their fitness adjusted down
as the cluster density increases - so there's maybe a natural balance
there. The good genomes will probably start to colonise the whole
geo-space over time, which potentially puts us back where we started -
a population dominated by a single 'best' strategy and no variation.
On the other hand it may lead to some interesting dynamics and mixing
of genomes, e.g. two strong colonies of genomes (deriving their
fitness from two distinct strategies) would probably mix (interbreed)
at the boundary between the colonies.

Colin
